{{Cleanup |reason=Messy and unorganised article; needs expansion for content. |date=May 2016}} {{Infobox Weapon |image=[[Image:Charioteer-latrun-2.jpg|300px]] |caption=[[Charioteer (tank)|Charioteer tank]] equipped with the 20 pounder. This gun is a later model which is fitted with a [[bore evacuator]] |name=Ordnance QF 20 pounder Mark I |target=general |origin= {{UK}} |is_artillery=yes |is_UK=yes |is_ranged=yes |used_by={{UK}}
{{Flag|Australia}}
{{Flag|Austria}}
{{Flag|Canada}}
{{Flag|Finland}}
{{Flag|Israel}}
{{Flag|Jordan}}
{{Flag|Lebanon}}
{{Flag|South Africa|1928}} |wars=[[Korean War]]
[[Vietnam War]]
[[Six Day War]]
[[South African Border War]] |designer= |design_date= |manufacturer= |prod_date= |type=[[tank gun]] |date= |service=1948-1970s |caliber={{convert|84|mm|inch|sigfig=3}} |part_length= |carriage= |breech= |rate= |velocity= |cartridge={{convert|20|lb|kg|sigfig=3}} |ammo_wt= |range= |recoil= |weight= |length={{convert|226.4|in|m|abbr=on}} |crew= |number= |elevation=+18 to -10 in Centurion Mk 5 |traverse= }} The '''Ordnance QF 20 pounder''' (simply known as '''20 pounder''' or '''20-pr''') was a British 84 mm (3.307 inch)Pugh, p.34; the gun is specified as 83.4 mm (3.283 in) here, while Ogorkiewiecz states the weapon was 83.8 mm. Norman gives it as "3.3 inch (84 mm)" [[tank gun]] It was introduced in 1948 and used in the [[Centurion (tank)|Centurion]] main battle tank, [[Charioteer (tank)|Charioteer]] medium tank, and [[Conqueror (tank)#Design and development|Caernarvon Mark II]] heavy tank. It was the improved successor to the effective [[Ordnance QF 17 pounder]] and the predecessor of the [[Royal Ordnance L7|105 mm L7 gun]]. ==Design and Development== The gun was developed by the Royal Ordnance Factories. As fitted to the [[Charioteer tank|Charioteer]], it ran through two models: *'''Model A''' without a fume extractor. *'''Model B''' with a fume extractor. The [[Royal Ordnance L7|L7 105 mm]] tank gun was developed from the 20 pounder. In 1954, the original version of the 105 mm was made by re-boring the tube of a 20 pounder barrel.Ogorkiewicz, p. 70. ==Service history== The gun was fitted predominantly to the Centurion tank, seeing action with British and Australian forces. One gun was fitted to a Swiss pre-production [[Panzer 58]].*{{cite book |last=Ford |first=Roger |title=The World's Great Tanks from 1916 to the present day|year=1997 |publisher=Brown Packaging Books Ltd |isbn=1-897884-29-X | page = 121 }} ==Performance== The 20 pounder's [[APCBC]] projectile had an initial [[muzzle velocity]] of 1,020 metres per second and could penetrate 210mm of [[rolled homogeneous armour]] (RHA). However, these conventional rounds were rarely used. The [[armour-piercing discarding sabot|APDS]] projectile had a muzzle velocity of {{convert|1,465|m/s|ft/s|abbr=on}} and could penetrate {{convert|30|cm|in|abbr=on}} of RHA.[http://www.miniatures.de/esp/shells-british.html British Anti-Tank Gunnery Data] at www.figuras.miniatures.deDunstan, p. 10, notes the 20 pounder's APDS round had twice the penetration capability of an 8.8 cm AP round. The 20-pounder could also fire [[high-explosive]] and [[canister shot]] shells. ==Ammunition== [[File:20poundercartridgecasewithHEshell.jpg|thumb|20 pdr [[British ordnance terms#HE|HE]] [[British ordnance terms#Round|round]]]] {|class="wikitable" |- !Round !Muzzle velocityNorman p12 |- |APDS |4,700 ft/s |- |HE |1,975 ft/s |- |Canister |3,000 ft/s |- |Smoke |825 ft/s |} == Notes == {{reflist}} == References == * Dunstan, Simon. ''Centurion Universal Tank 1943-2003'', Oxford: Osprey Publishing, 2003. ISBN 1-84176-387-X. * Ogorkiewicz, Richard. ''Technology of Tanks'', London: Jane's Information Group, Ltd., 1991. ISBN 0-7106-0595-1. * {{ cite book | authorlink = Stevenson Pugh |last=Pugh, Stevenson | year = 1962 | title = Fighting Vehicles and Weapons of the Modern British Army | publisher = Macdonald & Co. |oclc=10010960 }} * {{ cite book | author = Norman, Michael | year = | title = Armour in Profile No. 23 Centurion 5 | publisher = Profile Publications |location=Surrey }} ==See also== * [[Caliber#Pounds as a measure of cannon bore|Pounds as a measure of cannon bore]] * [[British standard ordnance weights and measurements]] * [[Ordnance QF 32-pounder]] ==External links== {{Commons category|QF 20 pounder}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ordnance Qf 20 Pounder}} [[Category:Cold War artillery of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Tank guns]] [[Category:85 mm artillery]]
